course.subject: CORE
course.name: Elementary Putonghua for Non-Chinese Language Background Students
course.description: The course is designed for non-Chinese language background students who have learned Chinese for less than 50 tuition hours. It aims to equip the students with listening and speaking skills for communicating in Putonghua for daily and social purposes through a range of learning activities. After successfully completing the course, students will have developed basic pronunciation ability in Putonghua, and fundamental listening and speaking skills necessary for daily communication.
course.exclusions: CORE 1412, CORE 1413, CORE 1415, CORE 1416, CORE 1421, CORE 1422, CORE 1423, LANG 1117, LANG 1120 (prior to 2022-23), LANG 1121 (prior to 2022-23), LANG 1122 (prior to 2022-23), LANG 1123 (prior to 2022-23), LANG 1124 (prior to 2022-23), LANG 1125 (prior to 2022-23), LANG 1126 (prior to 2022-23), LANG 1127 (prior to 2022-23)

reviews.author: Tayeeb
reviews.comment_content: Instructor DU gave us lecture slides which are far more useful than the book endorsed for this course. The course starts with the basic pronunciation of initials, finals, and tones. The topic ranges from Greetings, nationality, family, food, drinks, hobby, transportation, weather and clothes.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Instructor DU uses her lecture slides, which are pretty helpful than the book endorsed for this course. But I have used the book for extra practice since this is the first time I have taken a language course.

Classes are interactive, and she always asks if there are problems with the topics. She also tries to add some extra sessions for practising if you want to improve some areas in Chinese.  

She also gives you additional time in her office before the exams if you have any topic issues.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance is necessary for this course. Try not to miss more than two classes unless you have a good explanation (because they can lower your grade by one unit, e.g. B to B-). Instructor DU is very lenient on this part; one of my friends said he could skip up to five classes. BUT, you should not take my word for it. ATTEND EVERY CLASS.

The midterm exam is doable if you work hard enough. However, the listening part was very tough for me, so I had to practice extra for this. For speaking and reading, as long as you meet the requirements (which the teacher will give you before the exam) and the tones correctly, you can get fairly good feedback.

The finals have a huge leap in difficulty, the listening gets faster, and they mix the information here and there, so you have to listen to it and jot down the important points and find the answer. The speaking and reading parts are more or less the same.

Since this is a common core course, the grading is absolute. And they do not give marks for the speaking, but rather feedback.

My scores,
Midterm,
Listening - 13.3/15
Reading - 9.4/10
Speaking - Advanced-Exceptional (Overall)

Final Term,
Listening - 14.625/15
Reading - 9.6/10
Speaking - Advanced-Exceptional (Choice of Vocabulary)
- Advanced (Choice of Grammar)
- Advanced (Pronunciation and Fluency)

Reflection Task - Advanced-Exceptional

Blended Learning - 10/10 (Canvas Assignments)

Overall Grade - A+
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is manageable; find some good partners to do the assignments since they require speaking in a group. Instructor DU gives full marks to every assignment regardless of the quality of the work, as long as you submit them (Follow the instructions in the canvas properly).

There are optional assignments (they won't add to your grades regardless you submit them or not) in Canvas which are pretty helpful for practising listening and reading. At the end of the semester, you must write a self-reflection on how you approached learning a new language (strategy and learning guides); they do not look at the English skills but your content.

reviews.author: Dario
reviews.comment_content:
You will be able to get a basic level of Chinese speaking and listening abilities. I counted more than 600 words and/or expressions, plus the grammar concepts.

The purchase of a book (around 60 USD) is required. (You can also get it from the Internet).
reviews.comment_teaching: I really liked my teacher, Du Yingzi. She was very nice and enthusiastic about teaching. Sometimes she spoke too fast for me to understand, but that also prepared me for the listening exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading mainly comes from two exams. each divided into listening and speaking parts. I found the listenings to be very difficult for me, since I had never studied Chinese before. In the first exam, the audio was only played once, and the people spoke quite fast, so I found it difficult. In the second exam though, the audio was played twice.

At least an 80% attendance is required, or else the final mark is decreased by a fraction.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only four mandatory oral practices that consisted in recording a 3 minutes video of a monologue or dialogue. At the end of the course, a short English essay about the learning experience.

However, if you want to really learn all the concepts shown in class, you need to study hard, especially if you don't have a very good memory.
